{{coord|12|24|52|S|130|58|9|E|type:landmark_scale:2000}} (digital)| homepage = [http://www.ninemsn.com.au/ www.ninemsn.com.au]| }} '''NTD''' is an [[Australian]] [[television station]], licensed to and serving [[Darwin, Northern Territory|Darwin]], [[Palmerston, Northern Territory|Palmerston]] and surrounds. The station is owned by the [[Nine Entertainment Co.]], and is an [[owned-and-operated station]] of the [[Nine Network]], under the company name ''Territory Television Pty. Ltd.''. ==History== ===Origins=== NTD-8 was officially launched at 8:00pm on 11 November 1971, with the opening lineup beginning at 5:30pm with ''[[Skippy the Bush Kangaroo]]'', followed by ''[[Bandstand (Australia)|Bandstand]]'' at 6:00p.m. and at 7:00p.m., ''[[Burt Bacharach|An Evening with Burt Bacharach]]''.{{cite web | title = NTD8 Darwin | work = | publisher = Australian Television Archive | url = http://austv.hostforweb.com/cgi-bin/cgi2/index.rb?page=NTD8%20Darwin§ion=Television%20History%20Reference/TV%20Stations/Nine%20Network&mode=0 | accessdate = 2008-09-19 }} The station was officially inaugurated at 8:00pm by Northern Territory Administrator, [[Fred Chaney]], followed by speeches from Sir Myles Wright, Fred Yates, John Hickman, and assistant executive John May. The opening lineup continued with ''[[All the King's Men (1949 film)|All the King's Men]]'' at 8:30 p.m. and ''[[Danger Man]]'' at 10:30 p.m., followed by a station close. The station was completely wiped out by [[Cyclone Tracy]] in December 1974 and was off air for 10 months while it was rebuilt from the ground up. ===1980s=== NTD-8 did not run any news and current affairs programming until October 18, 1982, after the station hired Rex Clark as a news director to launch a nightly bulletin at 7:00pm entitled ''News at Seven'', alongside a current affairs programme entitled ''Spectrum''. In the late 1980s, NTD-8 was purchased by [[Publishing and Broadcasting Limited]], the owners of the [[Nine Network]] at that time. Following the acquisition of the station by Publishing and Broadcasting Limited, NTD-8 adopted a similar on-air presentation to the Nine Network with an ''Eight'' logo. NTD-8's news service revamped and rebranded along with the station, to become ''Eight National News''. ===1990s=== NTD-8's first competitor was launched in 1998, owned by [[Southern Cross Broadcasting|Telecasters Australia]] under the name ''[[TND-34|Seven Darwin]]'', now [[Southern Cross Television]]. The introduction of a second commercial television operator in the Darwin television market brought an end to NTD-8's solus commercial operations of the prior three decades. [[File:The-gardens-nt.jpg||250px|thumb|The [[Nine Network]]'s Darwin headquarters in [[The Gardens, Northern Territory|The Gardens]], [[Northern Territory]].]] Territory Television Pty. Ltd. attempted to gain [[Seven Network]] affiliation rights prior to Seven Darwin's launch, in a strategic move to dominate and force the incoming competitor to align with [[Network Ten]]. This would have seen NTD-8 broadcast both Nine Network and Seven Network programming, however after being rejected affiliation, the station gained Network Ten affiliation to supplement their parent company's Nine Network programming. ===2000s=== On [[January 1|New Year's Day]] 2003, '''Eight Darwin''' became '''Nine Darwin''', in line with the rest of [[Kerry Packer]]'s Nine Network [[owned-and-operated station]]s. Following the name change to Channel Nine Darwin, the station defunct [[Network Ten]] programming from their line-up, and in 2005, the Network Ten affiliation rights were officially relinquished, and were then taken by [[Southern Cross Television]]'s [[TND]] in [[2005]]. In 2005, in the midst of the tug-of-war for the [[Australian Football League|AFL]] television rights, [[Publishing and Broadcasting Limited|PBL]] announced that [[National Rugby League]] games will take precedence on the station over [[Australian Football League|AFL]] games, a sign that Nine may have be about to give up the race for the rights to a proposed [[Seven Network|Seven]]-[[Network Ten|Ten]] consortium, which they did, but not without putting in a [[Australian Dollar|$]]780 million dollar bid for the rights.{{cite web | url = http://www.smh.com.au/news/League/Darwins-wind-of-change-blows-for-NRL/2005/03/31/1111862534893.html | title = Darwin's wind of change blows for NRL | accessdate = 2007-05-19 | date = 2005-04-01 | author = Roy Masters | publisher = [[The Sydney Morning Herald]]}} In 2008, Nine Darwin (NTD) began broadcasting [[Nine HD]]{{Citation needed|date=May 2008}}. In April 2008, [[DTD (TV station)|Darwin Digital Television (DTD)]], a joint venture between the [[Nine Network]] and [[Macquarie Southern Cross Media]], began broadcasting on the [[Digital terrestrial television|digital terrestrial]] platform as a full-time [[Ten Network]] affiliate.{{cite press release | title = New digital commercial television service for Darwin | url = http://www.acma.gov.au/WEB/STANDARD/pc=PC_310217 | publisher = [[Australian Communications and Media Authority|ACMA]] | date = 2007-05-18 | accessdate = 2007-06-29 }} The same year, it was speculated that [[Imparja Television]] was planning to purchase the station from the Nine Network.{{cite news |title=Imparja takeover of Nine may be a step closer |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2008/09/18/2368379.htm |date=2008-09-18 |publisher=ABC News Online}} The deal would have involved the sale of the station, as well as its facilities and license. Negotiations for the sale of the station fell through on September 29, when Imparja failed to secure federal government funding to help finance the takeover.{{cite news |title=Funding refused to Imparja for Nine's Darwin operation |url=http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,24897,24415717-7582,00.html |date=2008-09-29 |publisher=The Australian | accessdate=2008-09-29}} ==News== Nine News is produced and broadcast live from the studios of NTD-8 in Darwin. Darwin [[Nine News]] presenters and journalists include:{{cite web | title= Nine News team | publisher = Nine Network | url = http://news.ninemsn.com.au/presenters/nt/ | accessdate = 2008-09-19 }} ===Presenters and Reporters=== ====Main anchors==== *[[Jonathan Uptin]] (Weeknights){{cite web | title = Nine News team | publisher = NineMSN | url = http://news.ninemsn.com.au/newsroom-state.aspx?sectionid=8754§ionname=newsroom&subsectionid=79943&subsectionname=NT | accessdate = 2009-04-27 }} *Michelle Buckworth (Sport and Weekend Presenter) ====Reporters==== *Leah Hannon (Court Reporter) *Justin O'Brien (Police Reporter) *Michelle Buckworth (Sports Reporter) *Michelle Fraser (Chief of Staff and Politics Reporter) ==Former Presenters== *Angelina Anictomatis (Sport and Weekend Presenter) *[[Lisa Andrews]] (Sport and Weekend Presenter) *Katrina Read (Room To Move Presenter/Producer) ==References== {{reflist}} * {{cite news | title = Tonight's The Night | publisher = [[Northern Territory News]] | date = 1971-11-11 | accessdate = 2007-07-01 | url = http://www.ntnews.com.au/ }} ==External links== *[http://news.ninemsn.com.au/presenters/nt/ Nine News Darwin] Nine News Darwin Team {{PBL Media}} {{coord|12|26|56.74|S|130|50|16.69|E|region:AU-NT_type:city(109,419)|display=title}} {{Northern Territory TV}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ntd}} [[Category:Television stations in Darwin]] [[Category:Nine Network]] [[Category:Television channels and stations established in 1971]]
